messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
>
> On 12/21/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...
> <mailto:jbrains762%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> >
> >
> > JUnit wants to make all tests isolated from each other, so that if test
> > #2 fails, test #5 can still pass. This is why it always creates a new
> > instance of the test class for each test.
> >
> > If you really don't want your tests to be isolated, then I agree this is
> > a waste of resources, but I have two questions:
> >
> > 1. Do you really want your tests /not/ to be isolated?
>
> You make it sound as if the only way to have isolated tests is for JUnit to
> create a new instance every time...

I merely wanted to test Vietchau's assumptions before giving too much
incorrect advice.

> There are other ways that are just as
> valid :-)

That's true, but that's not what JUnit does, and this is a JUnit list,
so I thought I would ask questions and offer advice within the context
of JUnit.

> As you already know, I think it would be nice if JUnit at least gave us the
> option.

For years, we have answered people's "how do I do X?" questions with
discussions about design. I no longer think that is appropriate, so I
didn't intend to get into a design discussion so quickly.

> Most of my tests have immutable state that is quite expensive to create, so
> using the same instance wouldn't violate the isolation since none of my
> tests will actually modify that state (they will just run tests against it),
> and they can therefore still be invoked in any order.

That is one safe way to maintain test isolation without having to
instantiate the resources each time. I have no way to know whether
that's Vietchau's situation, so I ask questions.

Most of my tests don't have expensive-to-create test state, so that's
the way I tend to avoid the problem. Once again, I didn't plan to inject
that into the discussion until I knew more.
